stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 12, a Wild West level, focusing on implementing a piano-playing Shy Guy character created by Zeina. The process involved extensive debugging of a critical RAM overflow and a null pointer crash. Key features added during the stream include directional audio for the piano and a dynamic NPC reaction where the entire saloon stares at Mario if he interrupts the music.

development_findings.summary: Adding a new character model caused a critical RAM overflow, forcing Kaze to immediately optimize the level's collision mesh to free up memory, highlighting the N64's strict hardware limitations.
development_findings.quote: oh shit it is Mario day it's a ram overflow we're out of memory cool cool all right we have to optimize the fucking level damn

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged and solved a crash by identifying a null pointer dereference in C, where the code was checking an animation's state before it was initialized.
development_findings.quote: What if because we check if the animation is at the end before we initialize animation, it's reading a zero pointer? Wait, that's definitely it.

development_findings.summary: Based on a viewer suggestion, Kaze spontaneously designed and implemented a feature where all NPCs in the saloon turn to stare at Mario if he interrupts the piano player, enhancing the level's atmosphere.
development_findings.quote: When the piano guy stops the music, the entire bar should look at you. Yeah, exactly. They'd be like, what the fuck, bro? Why'd you stop my jam?

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented directional audio for the piano music, panning the sound in stereo based on the camera's position relative to the musician to increase immersion.
Kaze explained a low-level N64 performance optimization he uses in his rendering thread to halve memory bandwidth by invalidating cache lines before writing, avoiding an unnecessary RAM read.
development_findings.quote: When you write 4 bytes, what you really do is you read 16 bytes, and then you write 4 bytes in cache. What you can do to prevent that is use the CACHE INVALIDATE DIRTY something something instruction.

development_findings.summary: The project is on Course 12 out of a planned 15, indicating it is in a late stage of development.
Kaze plans to implement a 'High Noon' dueling minigame against Boshi, which will require modeling a card gun asset from Mario Party 2.
Kaze is currently using the Fast3DX2 graphics microcode but wants to upgrade to Fast3DX3, which is currently unusable due to a bug that causes a 20% FPS drop.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recently learned about the concept of 'soft skills' (interpersonal communication) and expressed that this new understanding has fundamentally changed his perspective on his job and what is important for success.
context_findings.quote: Guys something insane has happened recently and it's changed my entire view of what I should do in my job and that is um someone explained to me what soft skills are. I thought soft skills was like knowledge as opposed to hard skills which is just like the brain cpu you're born with but no soft skills is how you talk to people. That changes everything.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels he has become too good at analyzing game mechanics, which prevents him from enjoying competitive fighting games as he sees them as mathematical formulas rather than games.
context_findings.quote: I can't enjoy fighting games because anything that's a competitive I just turn it into a spreadsheet simulator... they're no longer games to me they're just math formulas in a permanent loop.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarified that ROM hacking is a 'hobby' he works on full-time, alongside a separate full-time job as a programmer on Unreal Engine 5 games.
context_findings.quote: I am a programmer I work on games that we make in Unreal Engine 5 that is my actual full-time job... romhacks are technically just a hobby but I do work on them full-time so make of that what you will.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared his nuanced opinion on the Yuzu emulator shutdown, arguing that enabling a crime is not a sufficient reason to ban a tool and that the legal case was not clear-cut.
context_findings.quote: The thing about Yuzo and Chihiro's shutdown, I think they could have contested it and they would have had a good shot at winning... knives enable murder and knives are legal. I feel like in enabling you to do a crime, isn't really a good enough argument.

context_findings.summary: When explaining his dislike for a particular song, Kaze stated his philosophy that art is defined by the feelings it evokes, and his negative association with the song is tied to a past monotonous gaming experience.
context_findings.quote: art is about what it makes you feel and it makes me feel miserable. That's why. Because that is what I associate with it.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the model and animations for the piano-playing Shy Guy and his piano, which was the central focus of the stream's implementation work.
zeina.quote: Look what I made out of your Shy Guy. You're gonna love this.

zeina.summary: Kaze praised Zeina's vertex coloring on the piano guy model, noting she did a 'good job'.
Kaze actively showed his progress implementing her work to Zeina during the stream, indicating a close, collaborative, and personal working dynamic.

key_stories.title: Debugging the RAM Overflow
key_stories.summary: A mysterious crash after adding a new asset was diagnosed as a critical RAM overflow. Kaze had to immediately pause development to perform a low-level optimization on the level's collision geometry to free up enough memory to continue, demonstrating the technical constraints of N64 development.
key_stories.challenge: After importing a new character model and animations, the game began crashing upon entering the level, with no obvious cause.
key_stories.process: Kaze first suspected a different bug. After his initial theories failed, he hypothesized a RAM overflow. He confirmed this by temporarily removing the new asset. To solve it, he identified a large background object with thousands of collision triangles and created a much simpler, non-rendered mesh to serve as its collision, reducing memory usage.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified the RAM overflow and optimized a large mesh by creating a simplified collision map. This freed up enough memory to allow the level to load with the new character, showcasing the constant battle against N64 hardware limits.
key_stories.key_quote: oh shit it is Mario day it's a ram overflow we're out of memory cool cool all right we have to optimize the fucking level damn

key_stories.title: The Saloon Staredown
key_stories.summary: Inspired by a viewer's suggestion, Kaze decided to make all NPCs in the saloon turn and stare at Mario if he interrupts the piano player. He coded and debugged this feature live, turning a simple interaction into a dynamic and humorous moment that brings the level to life.
key_stories.challenge: The piano-playing Shy Guy was a static element. A viewer suggested making the scene more dynamic and interactive.
key_stories.process: Kaze immediately embraced the idea. He wrote code to trigger when Mario talks to the pianist, which then iterates through other NPCs in the area and changes their head rotation to look at Mario. He then had to debug a secondary issue where some NPCs didn't turn because they were paused by a 'time stop' flag during dialogue.
key_stories.outcome: The feature was implemented successfully, creating a memorable 'record scratch' moment that adds personality and reactivity to the world. This illustrates how Kaze incorporates community feedback to enhance the game's design on the fly.
key_stories.key_quote: When the piano guy stops the music, the entire bar should look at you. Yeah, exactly. They'd be like, what the fuck, bro? Why'd you stop my jam? I was vibing.

open_questions.topic: Balancing a Day Job and Full-Time Hobby
open_questions.context: Kaze stated that ROM hacking is a 'hobby' he works on 'full-time', in addition to his actual full-time job as a programmer using Unreal Engine 5.
questions: How do you balance the demands of a professional programming career with the equally intensive work you pour into your 'hobby' projects?
Does your experience with a modern tool like Unreal Engine 5 influence how you approach problem-solving on the N64, or do the two skill sets remain separate?
What is the psychological or philosophical distinction for you between your 'job' and your 'hobby' when both seem to command full-time dedication?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a recent, profound realization about the importance of 'soft skills' (interpersonal communication) in his professional life, a concept he previously dismissed.
questions: What specific event or conversation led to this 'insane' revelation about the value of soft skills?
How has this new perspective changed the way you collaborate and communicate with your creative team, like Zeina, Badub, and Biobak?
Is developing your soft skills now a conscious goal, and if so, how are you approaching it?

open_questions.context: The stream focused heavily on implementing an asset from Zeina. The other core team members, Badub (composer) and Biobak (artist), were not mentioned.
questions: We saw your direct collaboration with Zeina's work today. Could you walk us through the typical creative and technical workflow with Badub and Biobak?
How is feedback exchanged between the team? Is it through scheduled meetings, or a more asynchronous process?
How are creative differences or technical limitations navigated between vision, art, and music?

open_questions.context: Kaze outlined his plan for a 'High Noon' duel minigame with Boshi, which will require a new card gun model and will likely cause more memory issues.
questions: What is the gameplay goal for the 'High Noon' duel? What feeling or challenge are you trying to create for the player?
You mentioned needing to rip a gun from Mario Party 2. What's your philosophy on borrowing assets from other games to maintain a consistent, retro aesthetic?
You seem to anticipate more memory problems. Do you see this constant battle with N64 memory as a frustrating obstacle or an enjoyable creative challenge?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he wants to upgrade the game's graphics microcode from Fast3DX2 to Fast3DX3, but the newer version currently has a significant performance bug.
questions: What specific graphical or performance benefits does Fast3DX3 offer that make the upgrade desirable?
Is fixing the 20% FPS drop in Fast3DX3 a task you're tackling, or is it reliant on others in the wider SM64 decompilation community?
What new possibilities for the game would this upgrade unlock if it were working optimally?
